page.title: 10CHARITIES IN EDGEFIELD
page.content: A farm on the Barningham Road is oddly named Fuel Farm. It was originally owned by the parish and the income from it was used to buy coalfor the elderly. It has now been sold but the interest from the proceeds is still divided among the pensioners of the village who have lived here for more than five years. Two bungalows in the village are owned by the parish council: they were built for the use of elderly poor villagers in November 1916, with money from an anonymous donor. Another act of charity was to allow the bachelors of the village, if they had a gun licence, to shoot on land near Fuel Farm. The Simon Woodrow Trust has $2.50 per annum administered by the church to assist '5 poor and needy widows'.
